workflow.name: Automation Wf for "Create Wf Using Template" Feature
workflow.title: Automation Wf for "Create Wf Using Template" Feature

properties.name: Execute Workflow from Pivot Menu Pass/Fail
Create Wf Using Pivot Menu Template Pass/Fail
Create Wf Using Blank Custom Template Pass/Fail
Create Wf Using Incident Rule Template Pass/Fail

properties.description:
Test Cases Covered for Create Workflow from "Pivot Menu Workflow Template"
1. Creation of Workflow from "Pivot Menu Workflow Template"
2. Adding Action to above created Workflow
3. Execution of Workflow using Pivot Menu API's
4. Export/Import of workflow that was created using the Pivot menu Template .
5. Negative Tests (Invalid Template Type / Blank Display Name and Blank Observable Type)
6. Clean Up

Test Cases Covered for Create Workflow from "Incident Automation Rule Wf Template"
1. Creation of Workflow from "Incident Automation Rule Wf Template" using existing Rule
2. Creation of Workflow from "Incident Automation Rule Wf Template" using New Rule
3. Create Incident/Validate Incident
4. Get Wf Instance (Instance Gets Created when Incident is Rule is Triggered)
5. Verify Trigger Status
6. Export/Import of workflow that was created using the Incident Automation Rule Template .
5. Negative Tests (Invalid Template Type / Blank Display Name and Blank Rule ID)
6. Clean Up
properties.display_name: Automation Wf for "Create Wf Using Template" Feature

properties.name: Header Accept (Optional)
properties.description: The Accept request HTTP header indicates which content types, expressed as MIME types, the client is able to understand. The server uses content negotiation to select one of the proposals and informs the client of the choice with the Content-Type response header.

properties.name: Error Message
properties.description: Created Object Error Message

properties.name: Headers Cookie (Not Mandatory)
properties.description:
An HTTP cookie (web cookie, browser cookie) is a small piece of data that a server sends to a user's web browser. The browser may store the cookie and send it back to the same server with later requests. Typically, an HTTP cookie is used to tell if two requests come from the same browserkeeping a user logged in, for example. It remembers stateful information for the stateless HTTP protocol.

Cookies are mainly used for three purposes:

Session management
Logins, shopping carts, game scores, or anything else the server should remember

Personalization
User preferences, themes, and other settings

Tracking
Recording and analyzing user behavior

properties.name: Header User-Agent (optional)
properties.description: The User-Agent request header is a characteristic string that lets servers and network peers identify the application, operating system, vendor, and/or version of the requesting user agent

properties.name: Value (Only For Tenant creation) Provide Tenant id
Provide Request Body if needed (Ex: Create targets, wf's)
Select Method (EX: GET, PUT, POST, DELETE)
properties.description: The primary or most commonly-used HTTP methods are POST, GET, PUT, PATCH, and DELETE. These methods correspond to create, read, update, and delete (or CRUD) operations, respectively. There are a number of other methods, too, but they are utilized less frequently.
